1. Executive Summary



This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Sun Pacific Lerdo has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 



1.1 Sun Pacific Lerdo, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Sun Pacific Lerdo has updated their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following process which has the presence of a hazardous chemical above threshold quantities: 



Process Name                  | Process Chemical               | Process Quantity(lbs.)

Ammonia Refrigeration System    Anhydrous Ammonia                49,000



Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.



Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 

1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM regulation to meet Cal

ARP and RMP obligations as well

2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices

3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.

Process Chemistry

The refrigeration system employed at Sun Pacific Lerdo is a flooded and pumped overfeed system.



In the flooded system, high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped to multiple accumulators. Each accumulator is equipped with an expansion valve which expands the high pressure liquid into a low temperature and pressure liquid as it enters the accumulator. Each accumulator feeds one, two, four, or six bunker mounted evaporator coils located in the Cold Storage Rooms and Pre-coolers. The evaporators contain a set of continuous coils through which the low pressure liquid flows. Due to the low pressures and temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liquid refrigerant absorbs a great deal of heat from the surrounding area and evaporates.

To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporator uses an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid ammonia. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low temperature and pressure vapor, it travels back to the accumulators, through a suction return line, and into the main suction accumulator. Any remaining liquid falls to the bottom of the vessel and is fed by gravity into the transfer vessel. Inside the transfer vessel, the liquid rises in temperature and is returned to the high pressure receiver as high pressure liquid. From the main suction accumulator, the remaining low pressure vapor is piped to the suction inlet on the screw compressors.

 

In the pumped overfeed system, high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped to each liquid recirculator. Each liquid recirculator is equipped with an expansion valve which expands the high pressure liquid into a low temperature and pressure liquid as it enters each liquid recirculator. Low pressure liquid is pumped from each liquid recirculator to the bunker mounted and ceiling suspended evaporators located in the Cold Storage Rooms, Hallways, and Pre-coolers. The evaporators contain a set of continuous coils through which the low pressure liquid flows. Due to the low pressures and temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liquid refrigerant absorbs a great deal of heat from the surrounding area and evaporates. To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporator uses an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid ammonia. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low temperature and pressure vapor, it returns to each liquid recirculator and is piped to the suction inlet on the screw compressors.

 

The compressors compress the low pressure vapor, and it exits through the discharge outlet as a high pressure and high temperature vapor. The vapor is then sent to evaporative condensers where it is cooled and liquefied. The condenser uses air and water to cool the warm amm

onia as it passes through a series of tubes within the condenser. As the cooling medium of air and water draws the heat from the vapor, the refrigerant condenses into a liquid and flows to the high pressure receiver. The receiver serves as a holding tank for the liquid refrigerant being fed to the low side, and holds the bulk of the refrigerant in the system when it is not operating.

 

Safety Systems

The ammonia detection system is displayed and controlled inside the machinery room and pump room. There are three ammonia sensors installed at Sun Pacific Lerdo. Two (2) ammonia detectors are installed inside the machinery room, and one (1) inside the pump room. 

The machinery room is equipped with two (2) roof-mounted ventilation fans that are continuously running that can be used to reduce the ammonia concentration inside the room in an emergency. The emergency ventilation system can be controlled manually by the ON/OFF switch located on the machinery room roof, or the emergency break glass switch outside the principal machinery room door.



The Emergency Control Box (ECB) was installed in accordance with the Fire Code at the time of construction. The ECB is installed on the east wall of the machinery room and contains three (3) valves.

Valve #1: High Side Discharge Valve

Valve #2: Low Side Discharge Valve

Valve #3: High to Low Pressure Control Valve

Opening Valve #1 will evacuate the process through the high pressure side of the system. Opening Valve #2 will evacuate the process through the low pressure side of the system. Opening Valve #3 will equalize the high and low pressure portions of the system.

 

The Emergency Control Box is seldom used in a refrigeration system, but has been installed for rare emergency situations.



Each screw compressor has numerous safety devices to protect the compressor and the associated equipment from high and low pressure.



All ASME pressure vessels and positive displacement compressors are equipped with pressure relief

valves designed to relieve pressure and protect the equipment from rupturing. The relief valves on the high side of the system relieve at 250 or 300 psig while the low side of the system relieves at 150 psig. Accumulators 15 and 21-29 relief valves are equipped with a rupture disc and non-resetting gauge to assist in recognizing that an overpressure event has occurred. The rupture discs are installed upstream of each relief valve and are designed to break at the relief valve set pressure. Once the rupture disc gauge has been broken, the gauge needle will move to the "burst" zone, indicating that the relief valve has lifted. The gauges can be manually reset. All pressure relief valves are piped to the ammonia diffusion tank sized according to the Uniform Mechanical Code at the time of construction. This tank helps mitigate many of the hazards associated with the release of ammonia through a pressure relief valve.



The liquid recirculators and main suction accumulator are equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high level situation. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressor.



Process Classification



The ammonia refrigeration system at Sun Pacific Lerdo consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping. As such, the refrigeration system at Sun Pacific Lerdo is treated as a single process.



1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



Sun Pacific Lerdo has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an

accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 



1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia



The ammonia refrigeration process at the Sun Pacific Lerdo facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.



Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep active records of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 



1.4 Five Year Accident History



Sun Pacific Lerdo has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan



Sun Pacific Lerdo's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

- Cal/OSHA's Emergency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR ?3220

- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Emergency Action Plans - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38

- Cal/OSHA's Process Safety Management [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 8 CCR ?5189(n)

- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management [Emergency Planning and Response Requirements] - Title 29 CFR ?1910.119(n)

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 ?2765.1-2765.2

- USEPA Risk Management Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 40 CFR ?68.95

- California Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP) [Emergency Response Plans and Procedures] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4 ?2731

- California "Hazardous

Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 8 CCR Title 8 ?5192(q)

- Federal "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 29 CFR ?1910.120(q)



Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Sun Pacific Lerdo has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Sun Pacific Lerdo continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.



By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Sun Pacific Lerdo's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Sun Pacific Lerdo's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.



Sun Pacific Lerdo has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.

In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Sun Pacific Lerdo has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.



For the futur

e, Sun Pacific Lerdo now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Sun Pacific Lerdo employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Sun Pacific Lerdo will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.\
